content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
Early Access Review
								Paranautical activity is a rogue like game in a FPS format. the developer (accurately) describes it as "the binding of isaac meets doom". the movement feels exactly as those old school tittles. the movement is very important on this game, strafing and jumping are very important elements of the game. The rogue like-nes gives it change constantly the way you play and develop strategies while you advance on the levels. It forcies you to thing about how you want to build your character through the game even before starting.Paranautical activity is aiming at all the right directions. It has a fast peaced gameplay and a handfull of items to keep it diverse. However, what keeps me from playing are all the unfair situations i encounter while playing. Being too slow and have a room full of homming proyectiles comming behind you or entering a room with only one hearth left and have a machinegun demon spawn on your back is horribly stressing, and makes me rage quit. But it has that refreshing thing to it's gameplay that makes you feel like a badass when you cleanup an entire room, and always keeps you wanting more.This game has major bugs and broken mechanics, but the developer hears the community. these problems will be fixed over time, but i would wait until full release. This will be a purchase you will not regret at any moment.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
Early Access Review
								Paranautical Activity is one of those games I picked up during a Steam sale on the grounds of "it's three dollars, why the hell not?" It's pretty much an FPS version of the Binding of Isaac, set in an undersea Nazi fortress (?) populated with demons, mutants, and affiliated scum. Each floor is composed of randomly selected preset rooms, which lock until the player kills all the enemies therein. As you move down the different floors, more hazards are introduced, such as lava and bladed pendulums. Bosses battles are randomized, divided between mandatory (the room with the elevator to the next level) and optional, and an easy way to get free items. The game is fun, in an arcade-y "how far can i make it" sense, though it's not without problems. The dim lighting and voxel-based graphics sometimes make it hard to pick out enemies from the background, and getting movement powerups makes it very easy to run into something dangerous in the often cramped rooms. The different weapons are often more trouble than they're worth-the shotgun and the sickle are your best choices, hands down, and even then, you're at the mercy of whatever powerups are randomly generated in boss rooms or the store in terms of damage or firing rate. That said, the soundtrack is extremely catchy, and it's hugely fun dashing through the levels when you luck out and get the right upgrades. Though I'm not sure I'd pay ten dollars for it, it IS a fun little game.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
Early Access Review
								In its current state, it needs much more work. This is an early release game so I'm sure it'll get better but, so far, the controls definitely need a bit more fine tuning. The action is not very exciting yet either. I feel that there needs to be greater feedback letting you know when you actually manage to hit an enemy. Another problem I ran into is the inability to bind any actions to my mouse. By default, Bomb is set to Mouse 2 but when I attempted to change the button to Jump, the game rejected the change. On a positive note, the visual style is fun and all of the colored lights takes me back to the days of Quake 2. The music is also very cool and fittingly frenetic to match the game. I love fast-paced shooter games and I'll be keeping an eye on this one as I wait for the bugs / polish to improve. For now, I cannot recommend purchasing this title.

content:
Posted: January 20
												This game is fine, but it isn't very polished. It feels like a budget game by one or two people, and it makes a lot of rookie mistakes in its design. Everything is very basic, but doesn't feel very stable. Enemy AI is very simple, always firing where you are instead of where you're going. Most fights just boil down to repetitive kiting. Nothing is explained or discoverable. There aren't any tutorials or controlled settings for you to learn how to play, you're just dropped in and expected to figure it out without any signposting. This wouldn't be a big issue in some games, but because of how hectic the fights are, you don't get a chance to absorb information or experiment. When you inevitably die to something that blended in to the chaos fired by an enemy that blended in to the background, the screen presents you with the option to "restart" or "quit". "Restart" sends you back to the main menu. "Quit" closes the game. I could go on for hours on the tiny mistakes the game makes all over the place, but overall the game isn't objectively bad. A lot of the problems could be fixed relatively easily. Regardless, I still can't recommend this game considering how many other games on steam are essentially the same game with a hell of a lot more polish.The soundtrack is nice, though.

number of helpful: 7 of 15 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												I can see the logic behind the negative reviews. This game is not for everyone. It requires patience, reflexes and somewhat grinding for achievements - therefore the items. Now if you are not a fan of rogue-like, action genre, this game wouldn't be the best match for you. If you are, however and want to have some fun, this game suits your needs perfectly.I will start with saying that the game is really hard. This doesn't make the game frustrating though. After you get the grasp of the mechanics and familiar with the items, it will be only a matter of time to finish the game. David Bowie (RIP) is a playable character in this game (Though I don't think he would appreciate the choice of soundtrack.). Gameplay is fast-paced. That means there will be times you won't even understand how you died or took massive amount of damage. So never rely on your health being full. You always need to be alert and keep your reflexes up because the ways to die in this game are just too many.Like most of the rogue-like dungeon crawlers, RNG factor is significant. Game has six different characters with a huge item pool. There are many things that could make reaching the end a piece of cake. You can get the most OP items on the first floors, you can pray to RNG gods and get some ridiculous stats with the passive items,  you can find the boss room without too much wandering around the rooms and these thing also could make the runs really hard vica-versa.  Simple, pixelated, yet colorful graphics makes the game charming and kind of fits the style of the game itself, in my opinion. Music is... well, it is dubstep. Depends on your approach to electro music. Although I don't like dubstep myself, it fits the fast-paced theme and makes you randomly jump and shoot to everyone and everywhere, because the groove is real. Gameplay: 8/10Graphics 7/10Music: 7/10Replay value: 9/10Overall: 7.5/10, a good game for dungeon crawler or dubstep fans.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												If you’ve paid even the slightest attention to games in the past few years, you’re now very aware of what a roguelike is. Even games that have little to anything to do with the traditions of the genre have introduced randomness as a mechanic in order to take advantage of the buzz the term now generations. However, as ubiquitous as roguelikes have become in the last few years on PC, there have been few to try it in an FPS, and fewer still that succeed when they try. Paranautical Activity was actually one of the first as it went through Early Access, but controversy stemming from the game’s original developer delayed its full release to just recently, when a new publisher bought the rights to the title. It’s a good thing too, because Paranautical Activity feels like Doom made in a different age, and certainly deserves recognition for setting the standard of what a procedurally generated shooter should be.Want to know more? My full review has been posted over at my new home, TechRaptor.net ! http://techraptor.net/content/paranautical-activity-review-explosive-turtle-action

Roguelike games are increasing in popularity and branching out to different gameplay genres like first person shooters.  The curious design choice to not provide a playable character with a normal weapon is mind boggling.Enemy AI is very limited and has trouble moving, especially vertically.  As with most games of this type there are lots of things to unlock and explore if enough time and patience is put into the game, but from the jump it's simply not rewarding enough to justify that.

Early Access Review
A game would recommend. Paranutical Activity is a first-person rogue like-like, with an awesome overall feeling. Game takes place on a haunted ship, where everything is out to get you and you're out to get everything that is trying to get you. The characters are clearly destinct and have their own weapon. As the characters are so diffrent items you pick along your way effect the characters more or less depending on your choices. As many, I had my scepticism with an Early-access game, but if you can look past that, you can get into a game that's adding new content constantly.As a side note, the game hasn't been "abandoned" at all, that's a false rumor that's clearly not true, but still cracks me up every time, as it has become an inside joke that now is a pinnacle piece in the game's humor to me.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Firstly, I'd like to point out that this game is still getting more content added to it gradually. So this review is to reflect -current- gameplay and content.I have greatly enjoyed Paranautival Activity, and it has probably frustrated me about as much as Binding of Isaac has with regards to finding hard bosses, picking up bad items for my build, etc.If you like games similar to Binding of Isaac or Tower of Guns, this one is a great middle ground. The weapons all have their own advantages (Personally, the sickle is the best weapon in the game hands down) and each item is useful in its own right and can add interesting or frustrating abilities. For example, one item gives you the same jumping mechanic as VVVVVV has, that is, switching gravity and standing on the ceiling instead of jumping. It's cool, but can be a huge pain sometimes.The enemies are all interesting and difficult in their own right, and certain builds will find some enemies easier than others. I'd give the graphics, gameplay and amount of current content a good 8/10. I'm extremely excited about more stuff being released when the time comes, as I'm sure I'll come back to this game more.You should give it a try, seriously!

content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												I kind of don't get this game.From a technical point of view this is a quite fine game. This is a FPS game where every room and every level indeed is randomly generated. We have some patterns like a boss room or a shop room every level although everything else is mostly random.It's really hard to give a thumbs down to this game as it is technically a good game. This is just my personal opinion.Pros:- it's quick- four distinct character classes - different starting weapons, hit points value, speed and so on- randomness - after every boss fight we get a random item that changes our stats- nice graphics, looks like Minecraft on steroidsCons:- music is a dubstep mess - personally I don't like such kind of music although someone might find it amusing- this game is really hard. Maybe not Dark Souls level of hard but still hard- well character classes are distinct but only Tank starts with 9 hit points which relates to higher survival chance- I don't see a point in playing this game - this is only imoSo in conclusion - we have a technically decent game that lacks some kind of main motive. Or guts or spirit, whatever we may call it. If you like randomly generated shooters then go for it, it's ok, it's hard as nails, it's quick as Quake 1 and so on. I personally cannot recommend this game as it lacks something vital. I can't really describe this value in one words but let's say it this way - this game lacks a value that makes a player want to play this game. ---------- For anyone interested in joining in on completing your own backlog; check it out here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog/discussions/5/530645446320364338/

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												I wanted to love this game.  I wanted to so badly.Roguelike?  FPS?  Cool voxel graphics and that 'simplistic but awesome' lighting system reminiscent of games like Quake?  Multiple classes to choose from?  It's just too good to be true, it seems... and sadly, that's the case.It COULD have been good, could have easily been fixed and polished and balanced just a bit to create a fantastic experience, but in all the months and months I've had this game in its early access phase and even now after this 're-release', it's failed to address any of these issues.  In fact, all it seemingly HAS done is added a couple new enemies, achievements, and made shop prices even more impossibly high.  Great.The main issue is that it's simply too difficult.  No, NOT "haha hardcore fun!" difficult like your Dark Souls or Binding of Isaacs out there, but cheap, excruciatingly painful and unforgivably frustratingly difficult.  From the beginning of the game most rooms are PACKED with unreasonable amounts of every variety of monster and there is little strategy beyond  moving around wildly and hoping dearly that you don't lose too much health (which is generally far too difficult to come by, besides) as you struggle to fight back.If you're not lucky enough to be wildly powerful by the 3rd or 4th floors you're likely screwed, and by the 5th floor?  Forget about it.  I've never, ever been able to pass the 5th floor of this game in the tons of times I've attempted it, no matter how perfect my drops were, and this is coming from a guy who Platinum God'd the original Binding of Isaac and did all but the Lost achivements in the Rebirth version of that game.  I know FPS skills =/= overhead shooter skills, but I'd like to think my FPS ability is at least decent considering how many thousands of hours I've put into that genre over the last 15+ years and it proves I know how to weigh options, gauge danger, memorize enemy patterns and tackle various situations in action-roguelikes as a whole.. but no, I've never gotten past floor 5.  And I've only gotten TO it like three times ever, for that matter.The problem is, by the time you get there, so many enemies are... well, they are very fast, charge you, and deal damage so fast that there is NOTHING you can do about it.  No matter how fast you kill, they're coming from all angles, many types, and with traps on top of that.  And if they get to you, one of these melee enemies, from the sharks near the beginning of the game to the skulls and imps later to the chainsaw boss that you're almost certainly screwed if you ever fight?  The damage is so rapid that it's going to be all over, no matter HOW much health you have.  The game sorely needs a 1-2 second invulnerability period between taking damage, especially with how low the health values are, how much damage you'll invariably take simply exploring the dungeons, and how few and far between health restoratives are.  But no, once you're in the jaws of one of these melee enemies it's ALL gone nearly instantly, even if you're a tank with 15+ health and 10+ shield which should be an incredibly beefy amount -- it'll all be gone in about 5 seconds and you most likely won't be able to kill them in time to escape it even with tons of damage boosting passives.And did I mention they (aside from the sharks) are FAST?  Like, so fast that you won't be able to outrun them without loads of speed passives.  And did I mention that these passives only drop from bosses and shops, most the boss passives are jokes and you won't be able to afford 90% of the good shop passives by the time you get that deep even if you clear out every single room in every level up till then?  And that you'll DOUBTLESSLY have to buy some of the lesser passives as you just barely scrounge up the money to do so if you even want a vague hope of REACHING that floor to begin with?  Yeah.So there you have it.  An exercise in frustration in which you're going to be suffering through gauntlets of way too many enemies per room in such placements and combination that it's virtually impossible to avoid damage no matter how good you are, difficulty restoring the damage you took, and the knowledge that it's quickly going to become too overwhelming to even have any hope of moving forward no matter how good you are or how good the items you find are.  And no, it's not something you're going to learn and get better at despite the excrutiating difficulty like a GOOD action-roguelike; you're just going to suffer.  Period.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is great and all that, but it has a couple problems. -I don't know if anybody else has this problem but I do and it is to do with the performance. It's quite poor on my PC which is a large amount above the minimum requirements yet if I want at least 60 fps I need to turn the game down to either 720p or fastest. -Lack of multiplayer! Seriously! With all those classes you would think that there would be some form of multiplayer, yet there isn't. Huge wish for it to be there.Apart from that, the game plays great with the fast-paced shooting and the randomly generated levels make it just a bit more fun and give it a bit more replayability, however I don't see myself playing all that much up until the performance issue is sorted out or a multiplayer mode (One suggestion for that, have it so that you can play with random people, not just friends because I don't have any.) is made.

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												An FPS style binding of isaac esk game that i personally enjoy.About a year ago, i wouldn't have said that. The games community was a lot smaller. There werent many enemies, and everything just seemed... Unfinished in some way. But that my friends... Is not now. Now i would recommened this game to any/every one of my friends. The game has evolved to the point were it isnt just running around shooting everything that moves, it does involve some strategy. Example.. Going in to verse a mini boss isnt always the best thing, seeing how a lot of the time it can easily kill you, but at the same time, the item/gold you gain can really benefit you in the future.I could ramble about what i like about the game from here on, and what i dont like, but i'd rather just give you a list of pros and cons...Pros:- Good graphics- Nice soundtrack- Unique gameplay- Fast paced (which not everyone likes)- Tons of different enemies- Many bosses (All with unique attack patterns)- Tons of fun weapons- David bowie....Cons:- Cost.     Dont get me wrong, its not a bad price. But at the same time its not something i would aim for...- Enemy AI.      Sometimes... They're just so... Stupid...This game might not appeal to everyone, but if you have the money and generally like Rougue-likes and are also a fan of FPS i recommend this game to you.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like Binding of Isaac, you'll notice a watered down BoI feel when it comes to gameplay. It really suffers when you compare it to said game.. (Top down view will be missed, power ups feel very unneccisary, etc.) However, as its own game, it feels addicting, yet buggy. Controls sometimes fail when loading, classes feel very unbalanced at times, and the bosses either feel underwhelmingly eerie (rather than scary), or straight up punny (Note the nautical in the title.) Yet, when I got behind a class I liked (The Tank), I felt like a total badass Hershal. If you look past the flaws and accept that it IS a beta game, and ignore the blatant straight from BoI concepts... It's still addictingly fun.. It has issues, for sure.. but I'd still say give it a chance..

								At first, the biggest thing that put me off the game was the name. It's a really lame almost-pun, it just kind of gives me the feeling of "ugh, another crappy indie dungeon crawler". But, after legitimately giving the game a try, I've found myself really enjoying it. It's fast-paced, yet has some depth with different stats, items, and powerups. I find it very fun and it keeps me interested with procedurally generated levels.At this point in development, there really aren't many different items and powerups, but it is an early access game after all. After reading the update information in the community discussions, I was really encouraged.Overall, at this point in development, I'd give the game a 6.5/10, with certain potential to rise to a 9/10 by the official release.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								Buy? Maybe. (Note, this reflects an Early Acess game that will likely change over time, potentially negating this review. Dec 23, 2013).PA is best described as a rogue-lite FPS, where the gameplay mechanics are boiled down to the near most simple understandings of the FPS model. The goal is to reach lower floors, but I'm not sure if there is an end due to my constant dying. Nagivating each floor is much similar to the Binding of Issac and NES Zelda - Enter a rectangular room and clear the are of enemies before you can advance. The game controls near exactly like the original Painkiller and early entries in the Quake and Unreal Series - fast movement, circle strafing, and bunny hopping. The hook of PA is using your skill to stay alive with your limited health and advancing with a mix of your class weaponry, passive power-ups, and active power-ups. Classes include Crossbow user, Sickle thrower, Grenade Launcher, a Minigun user and a shotgun user (I forget the names of these classes, except Tank for the shotgun user). Each have their advantages and disadvantages in terms of weapon mechanics, secondary weapons (if any), damage output, range, and health. You can also get other weapons from gift shop if you are able to save up enough cash from them, which is often tough (Weapons seem to cost more than I have ever earned early in game, and when I do save up good funds, I'm usually on level 3-4 where I die). Enemies are varied, some which shoot a single a bullet or two every two seconds, some shooting a continuous hail of bullets, or even those that can nearly teleport to you for melee or enemies that can hop towards you and explode on proximity. What most shooting enemies have in common is that their projectiles aren't hit scan, so it takes timing, skill, and room knowledge to be sucessful. Each floor has a miniboss that usually provides a power-up, money, and sometimes health, weaponry, or items.The art direction is much like 3D Dot Game Heroes with an interesting lighting selection - where there are very few lights but each projectile also emits projectiles. However, most players will simply say something like "DARK MINECRAFT VOXELS WITH GUNS". There is not much sound assets besides gun shots, door openings, item chimes, and the player's "Oof!" from being hit. Much of the sound is in the form of a nearly rave-like techno beats that reminds you of other "Futurisitcky" games like Wipeout, Extreme G, or Forsaken.I actaully personally enjoy the base mechanics and idea behind the game - it's actually very easy to get a grasp of circle bunny hopping and learning when is a good time to strafe or sometimes stand still. You can skip the majority or at least the remainder of the floor if you desire, provided that you are able to find the boss room quick enough. The game is both easy since I am decent at shooters and because circle strafing the whole room though the entirety of a fight is almost always sucessful, but hard due to limited health, and the unprediticable nature of roguelikes (random enemies, random power ups, random room types).My main problem with this game is once you reach level 3 or 4, you often encounter enemy flying skulls which are often hard to dodge, can gang up on you and "combo air juggle" you against a wall, and what makes it worse is that they can get so close to you that are behind the point where your bullet will spawn, leaving you literally defenseless (unless maybe you have a melee weapon). This is compounded when you have a group of skulls that for me, seem impossible to deal with unless I'm in a room with a floor plan that will block them or at least slow them down a bit. And of course, like Rogue-lites/like (and Adult Swim games apparently) it needs to be punishingly hard, so despite me doing well up to this point, I die and have to start all over again. Since I'd like to clear my massive Steam backlog, "Ain't nobody got time fo' dat". But unlike other rogue-lites where it seems like patience, skill refinement and a bit of luck will help you beat the game, I hit this brick wall to completion once I meet these skulls and my enjoyment of this game is wiped away, much like my progress once I see that annoying Restart or Quit screen.Paranautical Activity is very enjoyable, but a fairly shallow experience, which is multiplied by having to constantly restart. If you are into the resurgence of rouge-like style games as well as old schoold FPS games, there's a fun and simple game to be found here. But I fear the skulls will kill many player's enjoyment.

content:

Early Access Review
								This game is amazing in literally every way. This FPS Rougelike game reminds me so dearly of The Binding of Isaac. Although it is rather difficult to master the game, once you do, you can truly start to see the beauty in the game. Now, I'm sure you're looking through the other reviews thinking you shouldn't buy it. I'm going to take a few seconds to tell you why those reviews are just wrong. First off, one of the most common rumors is that the game is dead, that is a baseless rumor. The developers of this game are still working hard in attempt to patch the bugs and add new features. Next is that the developers are jerks. I ask of you to imagine their situation, working to fix bugs in a game and all the communtiy does is complain about the bugs you are trying to fix. Wouldn't that make you mad? Then there's the bug reports, some people complain about how they are ignored or treated rudely on the reports. These are the same people who don't bother to notice that the very same bug they're reporting has been reported multiple times. In short, buy this game because it's worth it, and ignore reviews from fools.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												It's back, and Now I shall review it. it's a rogue-lite fps with multiple characters that determine starting conditions, many items to att abilities or change gameplay, from the simple goodness of faster fire-rate to the absurdity of vvvvvvv style gravity flipping. That said, it suffers from the same things rogue-lites all suffer from, such as repetitive gameplay and fiendish difficulty, but then again, games like this are supposed to be taken in bites.every floor ends in a boss, and there are several unique bosses requiring different strategies, and then you move on to the next floor with an item belonging to that boss.All things considered, I recommend it for the price tag and fun gameplay, so long as the game's rather troubled past doesn't spoil things for you. I had fun playing it, and if you like rogue-lites, rogue-likes, and other such ilk, you'll find this easier to enjoy than many others in that category.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												Do you like twitch shooters? Do you like games where you die a lot? Are you cool with having only one main weapon(which can be switched with other weapons if you find them)? Are you crazy for voxel graphics? Are you willing to accept or even enjoy a game with elements of randomness in which bosses you will fight, and which unlocks you will get? Are you cool with games with no story whatsoever?Do you like games with levels and a boss at the end of each?Answer "yes" to most of these, and you should definitely check the game out.For me this isn't a game I sit with for hours on end, rather one of the games I quickly log into for twenty fast-paced minutes, just to get that arcade game feel. If you are the type who is obsessive about honing your physical execution ingame to perfection, there's a chance you will love this.Good game, and at a reasonable price.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really want to like this game, I really do, but in it's current state and at it's current price, I can't. Paranautical is a rouge-like first person shooter, think Binding of Issac, mixed with Bioshock, which is a beautiful idea, and the 3D pixelated graphics give it a lot of charm, but that's about where charm ends, being a first person shooter, Paranautical Activity is very unforgiving, to put it in perspective I have beat The Binding of Issac multiple times, with multiple charcters, but with Paranautical Activity I'm lucky if I can make it passed the first floor. A lot of the trobule is you are constantly surrounded by enemies, which normally is'nt so bad, but like most FPS when you take damage there is usually a damage indicator, so you know which direction to turn and shoot, not with Paranautical Activity, so you figure that you'll use explosives to handle everything, well that's where another game breaking flaw shows it's ugly head, when you kill an enemy it burst into red pixels that skatter onto the floor and stay there for a few seconds, not bad right? Well every explosion also has a particle effect to the same degree, just orange pixels, so if you kill a group of enemies with an explosion you're in for a lot of particles, and unfourtately the game can't take all the pixels on screen, so it starts to lag real bad, and I know it's not my computer, because I can run games like Skyrim, and Dark Souls with no problems. So there is a lot of good in this game, it's got a great idea, all it needs to do is fix some bugs, but it seems like the developers don't want to fix anything, and until they do, or until they lower the price, I can't reccomend this game, however, if you can find the game for cheap, and you wanna kill a hour or two, pick it up.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												This is how not to do a roguelike. You can choose from 4 different guys, 2 of them worthless and unplayable, and 1 pretty bad. Then theres the game. Half the stuff you pick up on the ground you don't know what it is until you get it. Same for pickups from boss drops. Some items will tell you what it is called before you pick it up, but you have no idea what it does. Then theres the permanent items that you can't even read what they are, so you can't reference an item list from a guide. So you can be completely screwed. I was shotgun guy and picked up 1 slow down but more health, but i had no idea thats what it did. I was too slow and lost and had to immediately restart. I shouldn't be screwed bc of the game's fault for lack of info. Many items are just tradeofs, like temporary armor for perm speed reduction, which is just dumb and screws you, but once again don't know till its too late and you lose. There's no item list or info from the game about what items do, so you need outside lists. Enemies can spawn on top of you once you enter a room, leading to cheap damage. Some enemies also blend into floor and background, leading to cheap damage bc u can't see them, once again game's fault. Then there's worst of all. I was half way through game and first room I got had lava all over, and then these skulls that can auto catch up to you and you can't run from and home you and you get hurt. Able to kill them but took damage. Next level 8 skulls spawn, auto catch up to me, and I die in 5 seconds. It's so stupid I got auto loss when there's nothing I can do about it. Every room is almost the exact same with maybe some stairs. You fight the same 3 enemies each floor, and usually most of them on the floor above. Bosses are the only cool or original thing, but they usually just shoot colored balls at you anyways. You keep no progress. Can't start from higher floors. Keep no boosts nor money. You don't unlock new guys or any reason to keep playing. You get random unlocks from doing achievements but all that does is make it so an item has a chance of dropping now, which isn't much bc of the randomness. Very poorly designed how you can get into a room and bc of spawn there's nothing you can do  to keep from dying, and you auto die bc of the game, and lose all progress with nothing new to use next time or beefed up character to take going forward. Tons of better roguelikes, that are fair and well made that have incentive to continue playing. 3.5/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like intense shooters and don't mind minecraft-style graphics, you will have fun with this game.  It wraps elements of Doom  and rogue-like together to make a dungeon crawler fps.  You basically run from room to room, strafing about to avoid projectiles from various enemies while trying to elimate them.  You collect loot from enemies and clear out rooms until you find the mini-bosses and bosses of each level.  Each room is optional to explore except for finding the boss room which holds the elevator for reaching the next floor.  Each level has a gift shop that randomly generates 3 items to purchase with gold received from enemies.  The only major downsides to this game is that health is hard to come by at times and you cannot save your game when you quit.  This game is still in beta so improvements are being added all the time, possibly saving will be added later.  One huge plus is that they intend to add Co op in the near future.  This game is fairly hard at times and gets frustrating when you die but it is very fun and addictive.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								Paranautical Activity is a great rougelike that focuses on fast-paced gameplay, as opposed to the calculating style of FTL. Were I to categorize it, I would say it is a combination of a dungeon crawler and a 3D take on Risk of Rain. The progressively harder difficulty keeps you from ever feeling you have beat the game, especially since every playthrough is different.The character selection is also excellent, with several very different characters. All in all, I find the game to be very fun. It is definitely one of my favorites so far.

								If you like speed-run games, this is the game for you. The music playing in the background is very fastpaced, as it is techno,  making the gameplay very fastpaced. This game plays as a run-and-gun, where you go into separate rooms and they will start to branch off from there. The doors lock until you kill all of the enemies, so you cannot flee.There are normal rooms, boss rooms, and gift shops, where you use the gold you earned from the enemies you killed. There are also a few classes to be chosen from, but since this is an alpha, there are not many. For an alpha, this is a great game (in my opinion). Worth the money and will become addicting as you will want to play more and more.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								At first, I was pretty skeptical about what this game might be. A game that claims to mix the gameplay of Doom and Quake with the roguelike aspects of games like The Binding of Isaac? There's gotta be some major patchwork to be done in this game. And it's true, there DOES need to be additional content to be added. Right now, at the time of writing this (January 2014), this game is very much still a barebones basic game (and I'm not talking graphically). The gameplay is very satisfying. The level design is random each and every time, so it's got one part of its description on the store page right. It IS like The Binding of Isaac in that way. The randomly generated levels and mix of enemies gives one a feeling of helplessness and unaware of what will come next. Bosses are fairly tough, and defeating one, depending on which character you play, is actually quite rewarding. For example, fighting a boss as Gilead is very different than fighting that same boss as The Tank. The character stats, however, are not very balanced. At least all the characters have similar stats, and there's no real pros and cons to choosing one over the other. Out of the ten times I played, I chose Gilead 7 times and The Tank 3 times. Now, while this doesn't exactly seem like a good sample size, you can just look up the character stats online. All of them are fairly even and not balanced at all. I suspect this will get fixed in future patches and updates, and I do hope it does, because if these are actually the final character stats, I can't see myself playing this game much longer. Back to the gameplay, the FPS integration is absolutely wonderful. A slightly minimalist HUD, simple weapons, great gunplay. These are the cores of any FPS game in my opinion if you want a good mix of immersion and good gameplay. There's nothing really much to say on the guns and the FPS aspects themselves other than I AM very much reminded of Quake and Doom in the level design, specifically with the wide open spaces you often encounter in the many rooms you'll be running and gunning through. Overall, I give Paranautical Activity a 7.5/10. For an Early Access game, it's actually pretty well done. The level design, gameplay, and integration of two vastly different genres are definitely what I found to be unique about the game. However, as with most Early Access games, be wary: developers can just stop updating at any time they please. Vote with your wallet and read reviews like this one first before you purchase!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								What happens when you combine The Binding of Isaac and Quake? Apprantly whales. Paranautical Activity is pretty much exactly a voxel-graphic first person shooter with roguelike room randomization and slight RPG elements in the form of items.This game plays almost exactly like The Binding of Isaac: You go through a series of rooms arranged Zelda-style and have to kill all enemies in the room before you can proceed. The enemies drop coins which add a dollar each to your total cash which you can use to buy items from the shop on each floor. There are 2 bosses per level, a sub boss and a main boss, each of which give you an item when killed. Beating the main boss allows you to goto the next level. Room locations, enemies, bosses, and items are randomly generated on each level.Despite this being nearly the same game, it still remains a very fun experience. Being controlled in a first person manner adds some depth to the control scheme, playing very much like old school shooters like Doom or Quake. The music is amazingly catchy, although the sound effects are a little terrible (they sound almost exactly like The Binding of Isaac too). You have a choice of 5 characters to choose from, all with a different weapon (shotgun, crossbow, machine gun, grenade launcher, boomerang hook?) , stats, and playstyles.This game is still in beta, so there isn't much content yet. There's enough for a complete game, but items tend to become very familiar, very quickly as there aren't many of them to find. The crosshair is a single dot in the middle of your screen which is almost too small at times and there's no option to change it, so hope you don't need one to aim. Mostly, the game just feels unfinished at this point, though still very playable. Get it now when it's cheap and give it a try.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Time for a review with what I call "The hierarchy of what matters in a game" the first being the most important and bottom the least important~Story: The game doesn't seem to have any story, or perhaps it's less of a spoken story and more of a "your guess is as good as mine" story, but the feel of the game and the environment as you climb higher and higher is great.~Gameplay: Smooth controls, great aiming, sensical spread to the damage and the enemies remain difficult despite your improvement at the game, ensuring that every game is fun and interesting~Sound: The audio is simply amazing, the music is addictive on it's own even worth listening to on it's own! The guns have a nice sound to them making them feel quite real~Replayability: I can see stacking up voer a hundred hours in this game before I grow bored of it and that's if the game doesn't get more content through updates. With the updates I forsee 300+ hours.~Graphics: Greatly stylised old-school look, taking in the old pixelated guns and making it the style to make this game quite beautiful and always pleasing to look it. The dark theme keeps everything intense in feel and makes sure your eyes focus on what is moving.All in all: Despite my love for a great story and this game lacking an obvious one, I don't typically expect one out of shooters or most games I buy to lose a few minutes here and there. Adding that to the rest of the game simply being this addictive I can't say much more than it is a must try, the game is lots of fun and can even startle you at times and despite some of the enemies feeling a tiny bit cheap I associate that to my innability at aiming than the enemy itself being cheap.I do recommend!

								This was on sale during the holiday sale but I didn't get it, luckily it came with the humble bundle I just bought, and I have to say it is pretty awesome. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								Is there actually any other game where you fight a whale boss? If so, please recommend me one, because thus far no other game has pulled it off other than Paranautical Activity, that I know of.This game is spectacular, in my eyes. It's not just because of the shiney voxels, The Binding of Isaac-inspired randomly-generated rooms, the way I gasp in joy as I receive a pile of gold from a slain enemy, the wobbles and wabbles of the dubstep soundtrack, or the fact that there's a David Bowie class -- no, I'm being serious.Despite being denied the previlage to be put on Steam because of the whole adultswim business, Parantautical Activity proudly pulls off what you would call a Binding of Isaac FPS, if you just add lots of shiney lights, weird but freakishly cool creatures, dubstep and voxel-based graphics.Definitely try this game out, it's truly an experience, indeed.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like speed-run games, this is the game for you. The music playing in the background is very fastpaced, as it is techno,  making the gameplay very fastpaced. This game plays as a run-and-gun, where you go into separate rooms and they will start to branch off from there. The doors lock until you kill all of the enemies, so you cannot flee.There are normal rooms, boss rooms, and gift shops, where you use the gold you earned from the enemies you killed. There are also a few classes to be chosen from, but since this is an alpha, there are not many. For an alpha, this is a great game (in my opinion). Worth the money and will become addicting as you will want to play more and more.

content:
Posted: February 9
												Fantastic game. I would say this is a seriously underrated gem that most people will unfortunately look over. I have spent hours in this game. It is a single player rogue-like fps and despite being a single player game, I have spent countless hours playing with a friend by taking turns and switching over after each completed floor. The only thing I would suggest is to add  a co-op option where you can hook up with a friend and take on floors and bosses together. But even without that, this game is a blast to play. I'm not a fan of the music myself so I just mute the music but leave the sound effects on and the game is still intriguing without music, although it would be easy to play whatever music you want over it. I highly recommend this game. It's an easy time waster when you have nothing else to due.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												I'm strongly conflicted on this game.It can be great fun a lot of the time, but you will find yourself dying for stupid reasons more often than not... not once did I die and think that it was my fault, but instead usually down to some stupid item I picked up not knowing what it did and completely killed my run. For example;The "Eye of Dubbbz" item. I got to stage 7 and picked this up. It made all of the rooms completely pitch-black (until the end of the game). I literally just quit. Why is that even in the game? That's a stupid idea for an item, especially when rooms become more cluttered with obstacles so you run into walls like the Kool-Aid man and die+ Skill-based gameplay which is fun+ Movement is spot-on + Music is AMAZING (Produced by MACAskill) + Weapons are fun for the most part and each have their different gimmick+ Punny names for weapons and items which is cool- Classes are basic and just have different health & armour, weapon, and speed.- Nazi levels seem out of place- Bad items that are there just to be bad and ruin your experience- Gameplay isn't addicting like other rougelikes- Exploding enemies can spawn in front of you as the enter the roomParanautical Activity is mostly a game about movement, and I love how a lot of the items such as the Recoil Rifle allow for some top tier gameplay, To make the classes more unique I think each class should start with a specific movement item (Such as dash, double jump, small etc)The aesthetic of this game is also confusing... it's like a nazi, pirate, demon shooter? What?TLDR: It's a fun game, but I recommend you get this game on the cheapest sale and give the rest of the money to MACAskill (the music producer), as they shafted him out of payment and basically took his music.

number of helpful: 12 of 26 people (46%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Paranautical is a highly addictive game of chance,skill and on the run strategy.If I were to use another game to describe this one, I would say that Paranautical Activity is a 3D Binding of Isaac like FPS.This game provides you with a varied selection of starter characters (each with different stats and weapons) so it really caters to the individual's play style. During a runthrough the player can pick up so many items that they will become a personal class of their own, with no resemblance to what they started as.The player is provided three modes, two of which can be unlocked by completing the standard mode. Paranautical Activity becomes more difficult with each level you complete. Though items you pick up along the way will help you stay ontop of the next levels enemies.Each playthrough will be a different experience due to the complete random generation of this game. Differently sized levels, spawning different bosses, dropping different loot.If you are considering buying this game, the answer is yes.

												-OH WOW THIS REVIEW HAS HAD MORE ITERATIONS THAN FINAL FANTASY MAYBE YOU SHOULD READ IT IN ITS ENTIRETY-Developers are rude and insulting to their customers, and the game is slowly picking up bugs when it should be losing them. The game itself is really quite enjoyable for people who're into fast-paced arena-shooter type games, although it doesn't have the replay value of most action-roguelikes such as The Binding of Isaac. I'd give it a 7/10, although considering the attitude of the developers, the lying about features, and the increasing incompetence of the game's coding, I would regrettably have to advise against purchasing this.EDIT: As of October 2014 the dev team seem to be stepping up on taking community feedback and listening to the playerbase's concerns. content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												I might as well paste a comment I left on a friend's profile as a response to his rightful questioning of my sometimes hyperbolous♥♥♥♥♥ It reads quite a bit like a short review: I finally got around to playing PA and I honestly don't recommend it. Even ignoring the asshattery from the guys who did it, it was much less than what I was hoping for. Objectively it's not all that great. There's a huge lack of sound effects from enemies and part of the fun is that pleasing "plonk" that you get when you hit /or kill something in an FPS. It's objectively not all that great of a roguelike either as one of the best things about roguelikes are generally the items and what you can do with them. There is also a sizeable shortage of floors which is again something that roguelikes generally excel at.I kind of sensed this too. Which is why I was very nervous about the work or lack thereof in the future after they said it was "finished". It really isn't by any decent project standards. Is sad too because I love the aesthetic.Edit: Played a bit of the atonement edition. Still crap. But I appreciate what they're trying to do and will hopefully improve it rather than merely republish it.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit 2: I actually beat all the bosses a while ago on the first try, but stopped there because the game just didn't feel like much fun.What could be a great game is ruined by class imbalance, difficulty in aiming with certain guns as you dodge enemy bullets and lack of information on boss attack patterns.Heres a small example of why this game sucks:You are playing with a 3/3 HP class, boss has a lot of health, you haven't got upgrades or double jump because the game is just starting, you already used your few bombs on another boss. The boss spawns 5 spiders that quickly come at you while the boss keeps shooting fast travel speed bullets at you... and it keeps doing that until you are dead. So you have to move and aim around a small room with hill-like object placement, forcing you to stay rather close to the boss, but because the boss shoots with fast moving bullets, you can't dodge all of it because you also have to focus on evading and killing spiders, ESPECIALLY if you are using a single target, slow weaponhttp://paranautical-activity.wikia.com/wiki/SkullitoHere's another frustrating example:You complete stage 2 and pick up a powerup that decrease your speed but increases your damage.The next boss you meet hits you for 5 damage (5x1 quick hits because he's so fast) every time after he casts his special attack because you are too slow to run from him, even if you are running from one end to another, or around the walls.. it takes you 20 hits to kill him, but before you can do that, he's already killed you in 3 combo attacks. like, wtf seriouslyhttp://paranautical-activity.wikia.com/wiki/Hanz <---7/10, would not recommend at the moment.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								At its current state it is really boring.BUT DUDE IT'S A RETRO DOOM-CLONE, IT'S A RETRO QUAKE-CLONE.Okay, if you wanan play DOOM buy it off of Steam/GOG and put the .wad into the downloadable ZDoom application, bam now you got DOOM. Want Quake? Go to Quake Live's website, it's F2P, minus the P2W. They both do the emphasis on movement so much better. Also, if you call this a DOOM clone, you're being an idiot and I'd question if you've even played DOOM.The enemies are really dull, and are just hitscans. Yeah strafing is fun, but why not just play strafing in the game that does it best, Quake? i.e. why play ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Quake-clone mechanics when I can just play Quake?Okay, what about items?Oh good luck finding those. Binding of Isaac was a lot nicer about giving fun items. The items are dull. You might as well be playing Quake with a few mods, as this is basically Quake + Binding of Isaac, but being♥♥♥♥♥♥at either.Mechanics are uninspired, dull, and level generation is really dull too, AI is horrid.tl;dr it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Quake clone, with less fun guns, ugly visuals, and dull levels. Why play this when you can just play Quake?

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												If this was the pre-death-threats-to-GabeN version of this game, I would tell you to buy it immmidately, but that is no longer the case. The game at some point had an update that added two things that ruined the game for me: Slipery movement, and cringe-worty in-game achievements. By slipery movement, I mean that when you let go of the movement key, you keep moving about a foot untill you stop. 1 Foot may not seem like much, but being that platforms and catwalks are only about 6-feet accross in this game, it ain't a pleasant feature. Couple that with one third of the framerate of Minecraft (I can run MC at 60, this game at 25, dropping down into single digits) and you have a very rage-inducing combo.Cringe-worth eh? Padded: Tampon picture, Heh Heh Heh: 69, ParaNUT, stupid pun, you get the idea. Now that I look at it, I'm nitpicking at the names, but answer me this: Why did the game need achievements in the first place? Is such a short (Per playthrough) game not interesting enough without them?IMO; Get one of these instead, they both are far better games: AND/OR

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												This game fails on pretty much every level.Firstly, the concept: It's basically a bullet-hell game in-first person, giving you an incredibly poor idea of where you are in relation to all the projectiles that are incoming from every angle and making it distressingly common that you sidestrafe into an obstacle, get stuck and eat a face full of projectile salvo.Secondly, the graphical/UI design: Pretty much everything that isn't a projectile is the same colour of shadowy gray-ish mess, meaning that about the only way to spot enemies is their glowing eyes(when they have them), which are obscured by the helpful volleys of glowing projectiles all over the damn place.Thirdly, it's a high-paced, dodging-heavy shooter... in a game where every single area is a cramped cube often further obstructed by stairs and similar. This one should speak for itself.And then there are just all the gameplay issues. For instance, on the third level I encounter a melee-attacking boss who moves so fast that even at constant sprint away from him, even bunny-hopping, he constantly catches up with me and hits me. There's literally no way to avoid damage, hitting him doesn't slow him down, Nothing does. Your only hope of beating him is that your damage output and soaking ability beats his, which is entirely down to what pickups you've been lucky enough to get.Did anyone ever playtest this? Or did they just slap a bunch of things together and go: "FAST-PACED MUSIC. PIXEL ARTSTYLE. IT'S A WINNER."?The music's pretty nice, though, so there is that.(Also why would you saddle one of the playable options with a melee weapon when every single enemy is either charging towards you to make its own melee attacks or constantly vomiting bullets? It's impossible to use it without taking damage.)

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												 Game survived Gaben's ban hammer. 10/10 -IGNAll jokes aside though, there is variety in items, guns, enemies, unlockables, etc. But it all gets repetetive after a while. What I also didn't like is the fact that if you don't get a good gun/item 'till the 6th floor and have a bad superweapon, you're f*cked. I had a really tough time with gaanguses only because I had a crossbow and a cannon, and it ruined and lost the run for me. The only thing that kept me playing for 15+ hours was unlocking the  mystery man  and playing him, just so I can evade having a run where I'm like "Oh, I'm the tank now, better get some speed and damage ups!". The deluxe atonement edition is definitely better, but the game still needs some tweaks, updates, and with some luck, even new items/weapons. At this point you're gonna have approx. 30-40 hours at this game if you want to get all of the unlockables including the infinite mode. This game has very much potential, too bad the former developer team left it to rot.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fast, fun, smooth, and pretty, albeit too lean for its own good, Paranautical Activity is a fusion of old-school FPS and the ever-popular roguelike genre. Having a speedy, arcade-style shooter in a day and age where slow and steady is the way to go is always a welcome sight. The controls are confusing at first, given that the only way to learn them is through the launcher's configuration menu, but once you've got them down the game leaves you to your own designs. The rooms themselves are simple, having stairs, pits, tunnels, exploding barrels, and/or lava, but the types of enemies and number of them are just right to give the player a balance of control and chaos, while staying fresh each time around. There's also a lineup of high-octane Drum and Bass songs to run while you play, although they're knd of grating, and sometimes you get a few seconds of silence while the tracks are switching.While the combat in Paranautical Activity is great, the loadouts you get are rather disappointing. You choose package that includes a primary weapon with infinite ammo, a secondary weapon with limited ammo, and a number of stats including health, speed, and damage, although the concept of loadouts like this isn't exactly a nice one. There are no RPG elements either, aside from the various buffs and weapons you find in the game proper, so permadeath sets you back at square one. This isn't a big problem, but it really limits the replay value once you hit the difficulty curve.And from here inlies the biggest problem with Paranautical Activity: it feels very lean. Almost unfinished. There isn't much in the way of sound design, and despite the gorgeous visual style, particle system, and lighting, the game suffers from a lot of emptiness, even for a roguelike. After about an hour and a number of deaths, you feel like you've seen everything this game has to offer. Games like Binding of Issac have a plot and a sense of humor to keep you hooked. Games like Rogue Legacy have broad RPG elements and randomized perks to keep you hooked. This game doesn't really have anything. Even unlockable weapons would be welcome.Paranautical Activity is a good game with moments of real fun, and it scratches an itch that modern FPS games outright refuse to scratch. I want more out of this game, but it wears out on you about an hour in. If you and your wallet can justify an hour's worth of  gameplay that's fun and unique, then by all means pick up this game. It's an exercise in genre hybridization, but also in missed potential.

To view your achievements and stats in Steam, select "Community", "My profile", "View all my games", then the game and view stats.    Addicted: Spend all your money gambling.    Bottom Feeder: Complete a floor without jumping.    Bouncer: Beat any mode with Bouncer    Bowie: Beat any mode with David Bowie    Child Abuse: Kill Dahlia.    Chosen One: Kill a Tenchi while it's invisible.    Completionist: Beat hardcore mode having gone into every room.    Dynomite!: Beat any mode with Dynomite.    Finders Keepers: Get every item.    Frugal: Beat hardcore mode without spending money.    Genocidal: Kill 1000 Jimbaabwehs.    Gilead: Beat any mode with Gilead    Good Start: Complete a room without taking damage.    Gorton: Beat any mode with Gorton    Gotta Go Fast: Beat any mode in under 15 minutes.    Heavy Hitter: Beat 4 floors in a row using only melee attacks.    Heh Heh Heh: Have 69 bombs.    Jack of All Trades: Beat Hardcore Mode with all 6 characters.    Moneybags: Have 1000 coin dollars.    Monster Hunter: Kill every boss.    Nazi Hell: Beat the fourth floor.    Nazi Killer: Beat the sixth floor.    Night Vision: Survive a dark floor.    Not Even Worth It: Let a boss die to poison.    One Man Armory: Use every weapon.    OP: Have 30 items at once.    Pacifist: Complete a room without attacking.    Padded: Have more armor than health.    ParaNUT: Get every achievement.    Picky Eater: Beat any mode without taking items.    Progress: Beat the second floor.    Redial: Spawn two ghosts at once.    Serious Player: Beat hardcore mode 10 times.    Sure Footing: Complete a hole floor without falling in.    Tank: Beat any mode with Tank.    There's More?: Figure out how to get to the 8th floor.    Too Easy: Kill Dahlia without taking damage.    Tough Guy: Kill 100 Gileads.    True Victory: Beat hardcore mode.    Twice The Fun: Kill Dahlia after she spawns every set of enemies. Twice.    Tyrus: Run out of superweapon ammo.    Unsure Footing: Fall into a hole in a hole floor.    Untouchable: Complete a floor without taking damage.    Victory!: Beat classic mode.    Who ya gonna call?: Get a ghost and survive the floor.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								If The Binding of Isaac was a FPS it would be this game. Paranautical Activity is a procedurally generated, "Rogue-like", shooter. It's fast paced, similar to old Doom or Quake games, and has incredible replay-value, as probably expected from a roguelike. Especially the last patch, which added a progression system and 3 different play modes, added a ton of replayability. It's absolutely one of my favorite games ever.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Steam description : "Paranautical Activity combines the classic FPS action of games like Doom and Quake, with the randomness and difficulty of modern roguelikes like Binding of Isaac and Spelunky."Now where is the Doom part and the Quake part because I didn't see any! The game plays more like a slow paced modern shooter than a fast paced old-school shooter. The shooting feels bland. The randomized rooms feel repetitive. Also, strafing and jumping feel kinda clunky. Just on par with other crappy so called "old-school" indie FPS such as Rogue Shooter and Wrack.Aside from that, there is at least one thing Paranautical Activity is good at : heating my graphic card like crazy...If you're in need of some modern FPS with an old-school feeling made by indie developpers give a chance to one of these games :-Hard Reset (2011)-Serious Sam BFE (2011)-Shadow Warrior (2013)-Eldritch (2013)-Tower of Guns (2014)-Ziggurat (2014)Gabe Newworld did a great job for getting rid of this atrocity from the Steam store. Too bad it came back to haunt the living as a "Deluxe Edition" because I am now experiencing "paranormal activity", not Paranautical Activity...Rating :2.0

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Got this pre-steam and enjoyed it a lot. Mainly bought it for the advertised co-op, but the dev decided to cancel that. And the recent update forced a "Ghost" on the player, where it spawns if you take too long, forcing the player to speed run rather than plan ahead. If the Ghost get's altered to where it's optional or get's moved to some sort of Speed-run/Hardcore mode, I'll remove that complaint, but the advertised co-op canceled is a big slap on the face,I personally wouldn't recommend it out of principle, but in the interest of fairness, this is a nice fast paced action game with permadeath, though the Ghost is annoying.Edit 1: In a post on the forum, the dev claims he will be putting out patch that will make the Ghost only appear after you beat the game once, THEN it's forced on you with no other option than to delete your save(and cloud), to start over. It's not like there's some sort of progression system, but it's an annoying hurdle. Dev said that new players hate it, but 'veterans' love it, which I think is big assumption  thinking that only vets love it and noobs hate it. Whatever, this post will be updated when he updates and I'll add on details on his choice.Oh, and by 'no progression system', I meant progression that carries over between games. There's plenty of power-ups that make you stronger or have more health, speed, etc.Edit 2: Firstly, I was wrong about the progression system. There's an 'unlocks' menu that shows a bunch of things you can do and it'll unlock various things like weapons, characters, powerups, items, new starting/findable items for specific characters, and game modes. I think it's a very nice system.For the Ghost part: There are 3 game modes. Classic has no Ghost and you can't reach the 8th floor. Hardcore mode has both the 8th floor and the Ghost. And Infinite mode, which is basically Hardcore mode, but when you complete the 8th floor, you loop back to the first. Not sure of all the details for Infinite mode, but thats the basic gist of it.Edit 3: Your 'thumbs down' arouse me, keep them coming.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												This game is by no means a terrible game and to be honest, the price isn't unreasonable either.  But the reason I can't recommend is simply because while the game's over all mechanics are fairly solid it just feels very...well, soulless. The rooms are random and yet despite this fact due to their basic architecture you'll still somehow feel like you've been through the same dungeon a thousand times over.  While the voxel graphics aren't terrible the enemies still come feeling like they were designed using the most bare minimum of artistic design. Essentially, after pouring in an hour you're going to feel like you've seen almost everything the game has to offer.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Despite the great music and interesting visuals, this has not been a fun game for me to play.  It should be called Bunny-Hop Activity, because if you're going to survive you will be jumping around way more than is either fun or comfortable.  The concept of a bullet-hell FPS with perma-death, randomly-generated floors and item drops sounds great, but the execution here is really rough.  The bullet-hell is way too difficult to be fun for anyone less than a pro FPS player.Also, I they might think they're being cool by not telling you what the items do, and experimenting to see what is what would normally be okay with me, but it is totally unfeasible when you can almost NEVER get enough money to buy items, making experimenting really slow and unrewarding.  That, on top of the fact that most items have nearly un-observable passive effects that make figuring them our nigh-on impossible.  Couple that with the "usable" items and "super weapons" being unable to use until you go to Google to figure out which key does what, because you're given NO INSTRUCTION OF ANY KIND EVER.I understand learning by experimentation, and games not taking you by the hand, but it has to be fun and worthwhile, like a Binding of Isaac or Dark Souls.  This game is simply not fun enough, rewarding enough, or well enough explained or made to be worth it.We'll see what happens when it's finished, but unless you have twitch reflexes, and absolute precision I would avoid this game if I were you.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								Paranautical Activity is a very fast paced roguelike shooter. The combat feels like Quake on speed in much smaller, but well designed rooms (with enough room to bunny hop around while dodging enemy fire and shooting back).The enemies are nice and varied, and weapons are fun to use.In a nutshell, this is a mixture of the shooting mechanics of quake with the roguelike elements of Binding of Isaac.

								I saw a review of this game, and it looked cool. A FPS dungeon crawler with randomly generated floors and rooms. Sounds awesome! Then you changed the game. Picking classes at the beginning kills the suspense of not knowing what weapon you start off with. I died randomly at many occasions. Terrible default controls. Shift to change weapons? What?  And one class (Forgot the name) has a gun that fires spikeballs and a scythe that you can throw. Once one run out of ammo for the spikeball gun, using the scythe makes all the enemies (including the bosses) impossible because they move too fast. This is really sad because I can see a game like this being amazing but it just doesn't work. Of course the game is only in Early Access, so in the future the game might be better. But I can't recommend this game right now.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								Unfortunately in it's current state I cannot recommend this game. I liked doom and while this kinda mirrors that games concept it does not reach it's potential. It needs a overhaul in all departeemnets. I like the graphics, but they still need depth texturing and rendering in order for a decent amount of valid perception. The lighting however is great. The sound is what really disrupts it's plaaaaayability. The music is annoying and needs different tracks with ambience. Also needs gamepad aassimilation and a story campaign.Basiclly the game needs a complete restructuring with the same lighting and graphics style with enhanced texturing and shadows.

number of helpful: 6 of 21 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Gameplay is just like Serious Sam: Walk into room. All enemies either run at you or start shooting slow projectiles. Kill them all. Repeat.One key difference is that the enemies are dead silent, rather dimly lit, and deal a lot of damage. When you walk into a new room, you can easily run backwards into a 12 foot high Satan and lose three hearts in an instant. You would think that this would make the game unplayable, but the number of different room layouts is so small that you will start remembering enemy spawn locations after a couple games.Since the game is rogue-like, it is really tempting to play round after round in order to see new items. However, few items really change how the game is played. You are going to be running backward holding down your left mouse button a lot.I only got as far as the floor where swastikas start appearing on walls and tiny fast moving raptors run at you (6th? 8th? I don't remember). That is when I realized I would have to memorize a whole new area of layouts, and that I had stopped having fun four hours ago. Could it appeal to some people? Maybe. Could it improve? Maybe. I would not recommend buying it now.

number of helpful: 12 of 38 people (32%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												DO NOT BUT THIS GAME.this is literally one of the worst games i've ever played in my life.the aesthetics are universally offensive. graphics are hideous, enemy and weapon designs are laughable, music is eardrum-bludgeoning garbage. the weapons themselves are horribly unfun to use, with no sense of weight to them and no sense that they are inflicting damage on anything you aim them with. every audio asset in this game is stolen. enemies don't even react when you shoot them, whether it be with a crossbow or a grenade launch. even wolf3d and doom gave you enough feedback that it felt like you were firing weapons that damaged the target, something that this title has completely failed to do. all of this might have been forgivable if the game was in any way enjoyable to play, but to top everything else off it also controls like steaming garbage. you move like a greased pig on ice skates and the limited field of view and terrible movement guarantees that you will get hung up on the slightest obstacle in your path.the real crime here isn't that this game was yanked from greenlight, it's that it was ever allowed on steam to begin with, and i sincerely regret that even a single cent of my money has gone into the developers' pockets.EDIT: since i have written this, this game has been taken off steam because Mike "SpooderW" Maulbeck threatened to murder Gabe Newell on Twitter. at this point this miserable software abortion was removed from steam and Maulbeck resigned from code avarice. except code avarice hired him again and sold this garbage heap to another publisher to get it back on Steam. do not pay for this game. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME.DOUBLE EDIT: I have been permabanned from this game's forums lmfao.TRIPLE EDIT: I have been unbanned. This game is still bad.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								This isn't a run and gun game. Its run, gun, and try not to die game. This was as if Dark Souls, Doom, and Binding of Isaac were thrown into a blender and this is the outcome. Its a really great shooter, it reminds of retro shooters where there is no regenerative health. The graphics are really cool, they have voxel like graphics which is really creative. It's also worth mentioning that when the enemies explode into items and red voxels which gives you the satistfaction of killing an enemy, and gets you pumped for more action (along with the door sounds opening when you clear a room). There is a HUGE variety of enemies and bossess as well, so won't get generic grunts all the time. The music is very awesome, it makes you pumped up and ready to kick some butt. The only problem is that there is barely any sound effects, the only sounds are doors opening, collecting items, and your weapon noises.Overall this game is really great and I highly recomend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have this game on Steam, and I really enjoy it. Here's a breakdown of the short while I've been playing it.PROS- Fast-paced do-or-die action gameplay- Variety of weapons and classes (recently updated and balanced, every class now also has a secondary weapon)- Variety of enemies (recently updated with a rocket turtle :D)- Recently updated "free weapon" door (you'll see when you play)CONS- You can get stuck under stairs (a pain, given you only have a few hits and no recovery time between hits)- Some boss doors have pentagrams (a moral preference)- Some bosses seem unbeatable based on your class (some you need to outrun, like the Snail Skull, but the Tank class is too slow)NEUTRAL (Pro or Con based on preference)- Unoriginal cubed "Minecraft" look- Can't change the music (I happen to like some songs. I've heard by others that they are obnoxious)TIPS- Don't stop moving- Try out all the classes for their weapons to see if you like them before you buy replacements in the gift shop- Don't underestimate those little dudes... they are surpisingly accurate.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								From a mechanics standpoint, I cannot recommend this game. It's like they took a good control scheme and deliberatly made it worse. Your character controls awful, and while normally the retro atmosphere would be enough to do it for me this game feels... clunky, I guess?The boss fights are terrific, but the lack of variety is the real killer for me. I guess the plan was to try and let the randomly generated content make for lots of replayability, but the game is to short to get any unique experiences. The roguelike mechanic just ends up feeling like a padding technique in the end. Nice idea, but poorly executed.Then there's the elephant in the room - The Public Relations.These guys are terrible at PR. There have been allegations of censorship, insilts made to the gaming comunity, and several instances of trolls provoking negative responses. It's my personal belief that this is the reason this game was "finished" early - It's not a case of the goals of the developer being met, it's that they just want it to be done with.I would suggest picking up the games it was inspired from - you'll get a lot more gameplay, for substantially less cost.

								This is a pretty fun game. Full of challenge, explosions, and pain. If you're good at twitch style FPS games you'll start out without much of a challenge at first but once you go up a few floors it really kicks it into high gear with the difficulty. If you like difficulty, the voxel style, and FPS arena shooters I'd recommend this game to you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								If you throw Binding Of Isaac, Quake and Minecraft into a blender, you would get Paranautical Acitivty.Even in and early state, this game is a lot of fun but clearly lacking features.You start the game choosing presets of weapons, so far I prefer the shotgun although you dont get a secondary weapon and it is slow, so it has its cons.It uses a similar random room system as Binding Of Isaac which helps keep the game from feeling non linear, In its current state you will be facing the same type of enemy a lot.So far I have seen maybe 4 or 5 types of enemies excluding boss battles.It controls like a twitch shooter like the early days of quake, and gaining powerups to double jump etc. adds a lot of fun jumping and dodging bullets around the rooms.The minecraft esque graphics look beautiful with a great lighting system. When you destroy enemies and explosive barrel's you will see a lot of 'particle' like effects which look great.In its current state I would give this game a 6/10, I have not read about the upcoming features but this could easily be a 7 or 8/10 game when it is completed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
Early Access Review
								Paranautical Activity is an excellent roguelike dungeon-crawling shooter, with simple humbling textures, and a charming implementation of voxels. This game's satisfaction, consisting of fighting off hordes of demonspawn, and cracking open phat lewts is only matched by that of the speed and finesse the player as they weave and blast their way through randomly generated rooms. All set to a spicy hardcore techno beat, valliantly played through the entire game.In addition to promised future updates, Paranautical Activity is absolutely worth the purchase to support its development. I personally await anxiously to play this game again in the future when I have a computer with enough hardware capacity to play this game without strong lag.      8/10
